questions.question: 3. When faced with a project at work, which picture best represents your natural approach?
answers: A. Strategist
B. Urgent
C. Planning
D. Discussion

questions.question: 4. If a colleague repeatedly misses deadlines, affecting your ability to meet your targets on a critical project, how does that initially make you feel?
answers: A. Angry
B. Frustrated
C. Empathetic
D. Curious

questions.question: 5. A colleague has completed a piece of work that you believe is good, and they are clearly proud of it. However, the deadline has arrived, and while the work needs to be delivered now, you notice a few small...
answers: A. Explain to them then and there the few tiny ways that their work could be better.
B. Celebrate them for producing a good piece of work and delivering it on time.
C. Make a note for future reference. Next time a project like this comes up, tell them before they start.
D. Protect their morale, the work is good enough, move on to the next project.
E. Quickly make the tiny edits yourself. Find a better moment to give them feedback in the future.

questions.question: 6. You wake up at 9 a.m. to 20 emails from your most important clients. Overnight, someone hacked your email account and sent highly specific, abusive messages—pretending to be you—targeting your clients...
answers: A. Very high emotion
B. High emotion
C. Neutral
D. Low emotion
E. Very low emotion

questions.question: 7. You've been working on a project for six months, and it’s nearly complete, with a launch planned for next week. At the last minute, you receive an email from your manager informing you that the project has been...
answers: A. Very happy
B. Happy
C. Neutral
D. Sad
E. Very sad

questions.question: 8. Select the three factors that matter most to you professionally.
answers: A. Your team and those you work with being happy
B. Making sure every single piece of work you produce is perfect
C. Being recognised for the contributions that you make
D. Avoiding burnout and working at a sustainable pace
E. Leading and inspiring others to achieve their best
F. Ensuring the company upholds strong social and political values
G. Beating close competitors and becoming No.1 in your industry
H. Having sufficient time, encouragement and guidance from a supportive line manager.

questions.question: 9. I strive to keep my work and personal life separate.
10. The people I work with would likely describe me as impatient.
11. I prefer to make a decision now and correct it later if necessary, rather than spend extra time planning, discussing, and gathering information.
12. I set goals that others I work with may view as too ambitious or unrealistic.
13. I often find myself getting annoyed that colleagues of mine don't work as hard as me.
14. It is important to me to work with people who share my social and political values.

15. Despite receiving feedback and coaching, a team member continues to deliver work below expectations, misses deadlines, and slows down the team’s progress. However, they are well-liked by the team. As the...
answers: A. Offer support and guidance
B. Address the issue in a private meeting to discuss concerns and create a performance improvement plan
C. Provide additional training and resources to help the team member improve
D. Consider reassigning tasks or seeking external help if the situation persists
E. Initiate the process to remove the team member from the company

questions.question: 16. You are responsible for organising a major event in four weeks, but the only available supplier for essential items informs you that delivery will take six weeks. How do you respond?
answers: A. Tweak the event to make sure it can go ahead in 4 weeks. Remove items that will take too long to arrive.
B. Move the date of the event back by 2 weeks to make sure you can deliver the event in the way you initially planned.
C. Ask the supplier to explain to you in detail why it takes 6 weeks to arrive?

questions.question: 17. You're leading the sales team at Flight Story. It’s December 15th, the final day before the office closes for Christmas, and despite significant effort and hard work, your team is still £1M short of the £30M annual target. How do you respond?
answers: A. Express appreciation and gratitude to the team for a great effort this year.
B. Increase next year's target by £1M to make up for the deficit.
C. Use it as a learning opportunity to figure out how to meet targets next year and deliver the feedback.
D. Rally the team for a final push and remind them that the year is not done.
E. Wonder if you set the target too high, because the team did work hard all year.
F. Let the team finish for the year, but work through the holiday season yourself to try and hit the target.

questions.question: 18. A client messages you on WhatsApp on Saturday evening while you're out with friends at a restaurant. They need the login details for their social media account, but your colleague, who has the details, is on holiday. How do you respond?
answers: A. Message the client back on WhatsApp and let them know that you'll send the password over first thing in the morning.
B. Wait until you're back home on Sunday morning, and send the client an email explaining the delay.
C. WhatsApp your colleague who is on holiday straight away and ask them for the login details.
D. Wait until you're back home on Sunday and contact your colleague via email to ask for the login details.

questions.question: 19. The CEO assigns you a critical piece of work to deliver with your team, but the deadline is extremely tight, and you're unsure if your team can complete it on time. How do you respond?
answers: A. Ask the CEO if the deadline can be slightly extended to give the team more time to meet it comfortably.
B. Find clever ways to scale back the scope of the work so that it can be delivered in 5 days.
C. Rally your team to meet the deadline even though you believe it's going to be extremely tight.
D. Find freelance talent that can help and delegate as much of the work as possible to external teams.

questions.question: 20. You and your team fly into New York to record an important podcast over the weekend with a high-profile guest. This opportunity has taken a long time to arrange, and the guest is set to board a plane in two hours. How do you respond?
answers: A. Contact the high-profile guest's team and let them know there has been an issue, advising them not to travel yet.
B. Don't inform the guest about the issue, scale down the production, and figure out how to film the content another way.
C. Don't contact the guest, let them travel, and assume you can figure it out before they arrive.
D. Tell the guest's team what has happened and ask them if they can bring the camera equipment themselves.

questions.question: 21. How would you feel inside if the CEO asked you to analyse the data and analytics of a project?
answers: A. Excited
B. Concerned

questions.question: 22. How do you feel about the current developments in artificial intelligence?
answers: A. Confused
B. Scared
C. Excited
D. Mindblown
E. Hiding
F. Thrilled

questions.question: 23. You receive an email from a long-time customer who is unhappy with a product they purchased. They are demanding a refund and threatening to leave a negative review. However, company policy states that...
answers: A. Apologise, explain the refund policy, and politely deny their request.
B. Offer a discount on their next purchase to maintain a positive relationship.
C. Issue a full refund to keep the customer happy, even if it goes against policy.
D. Escalate the issue to your manager to make the decision.

questions.question: 24. You're leading a team on a major project, but an unexpected delay has put you behind schedule. The deadline is in 24 hours, and if the project isn't delivered on time, it could be cancelled. Your team is...
answers: A. Push the team to work even harder and ensure the project is completed, even if quality suffers.
B. Identify the most critical aspects of the project, focus on those, and communicate with stakeholders.
C. Request an extension from leadership, citing the unexpected challenges.
D. Accept that the deadline will be missed and focus on delivering a flawless result later.

questions.question: 25. Two of your teammates disagree on the best approach to completing a task. Their conflict is slowing progress, and their communication has become tense. Other team members are becoming distracted by...
answers: A. Step in as a mediator, listen to both sides, and help them find a compromise.
B. Allow them to resolve it on their own, assuming they will figure it out.
C. Choose the approach you think is best and instruct the team to follow it.
D. Escalate the issue to your manager instead of getting involved.

questions.question: 26. You are presenting an important report to leadership when a critical technical error occurs—your slides won’t load, and your laptop freezes. Leadership is expecting data-driven insights, and you have five minutes. How do you respond?
answers: A. Apologise for the issue and reschedule the meeting when you can properly present.
B. Deliver the key insights from memory and summarise the most important points verbally.
C. Try to fix the issue in real time while keeping leadership waiting.
D. Ask leadership if you can email the full report later instead of presenting now.

questions.question: 27. A team member has consistently missed deadlines and delivered incomplete work. Other teammates are picking up their slack, and team morale is starting to decline. Despite previous feedback, their performance has not improved. How do you respond?
answers: A. Have another conversation with the team member and give them a final chance to improve.
B. Document their performance issues and escalate it to HR or leadership.
C. Continue covering for them to protect team morale and give them more time to improve.
D. Call them out in a team meeting to make them accountable.

questions.question: 28. Your company is implementing a new workflow designed to improve efficiency, but many employees are resistant to the change. Some believe it will initially slow them down, making them hesitant to adopt it. How do you handle this?
answers: A. Encourage the team by explaining how the change benefits them long-term.
B. Listen and let them continue using the old process if they want to while you try and implement changes.
C. Force immediate compliance, as it's a company decision.
D. Provide hands-on training to make the transition easier.

questions.question: 29. A major client sends an urgent request on Christmas Eve, but the entire team is out of the office for the holidays. How do you handle the situation?
answers: A. Inform the client that the team is out for the holidays but offer a workaround, such as a temporary fix.
B. Assess the urgency of the request, inform leadership if necessary, and communicate clearly with the client.
C. Politely explain that the company observes the holiday break and the request will be handled as soon as possible.
D. Personally step in to handle the request or find an available team member who can assist. If needed, adjust priorities.

questions.question: 30. You need a social media manager to launch a new social media page for a medium-priority project. However, the recruitment team informs you that due to a hiring backlog, it will take 3–6 months to find the right candidate. How do you proceed?
answers: A. Push back on the hiring backlog, escalate the urgency to leadership, and negotiate a faster hiring process.
B. Accept the hiring delay but use the time smartly to plan strategy, content, and branding so the new hire can hit the ground running.
C. Explore hiring a freelancer, contractor, or agency to launch the page while the recruitment process continues.
D. Log on to LinkedIn and try to headhunt a suitable candidate yourself without the support of the recruitment team.

questions.question: 31. You've hired an email marketing manager for a new company newsletter and also brought on a writer to create content. The team is divided—half want to spend eight more weeks researching the newsletter, while the other half wants to launch quickly. How do you proceed?
answers: A. Spend the full 8 weeks researching and planning to make sure the newsletter is a huge success.
B. Spend 4 more weeks researching the newsletter landscape, that should be enough time.
C. Tell the team you want to launch it as soon as possible and prepare the first draft to launch in 1 week.

questions.question: 32. When I produce poor-quality work in a professional setting, it is usually because:
answers: A. The team I'm working with have let me down.
B. The client didn't give me clear enough instructions.
C. I wasn't given the guidance and support I needed to succeed.
D. I didn't try as hard as I could have, and I know I could have done better.

questions.question: 33. A team member presents a strategic plan during a group meeting for an upcoming project. You notice a small issue in the strategy. How do you handle the situation?
answers: A. Let them finish their presentation and find a time later to quietly mention the issue to them in private.
B. Raise the issue in the meeting then and there, in front of the whole team.
C. The presentation was good, don't make a big issue over a small issue.
D. Gently ask questions that will slowly guide the person presenting to spot the issue themselves.
